intro: Galeatella × kauaensis, commonly known as the Kauaʻēnō or Hawaiian false hibiscus, is a hybrid plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, with woody stems and large, heart-shaped leaves. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and lowland areas. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it is considered a rare and endangered species in the wild.
